subject: RE: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Letter #26?
msgSnippet: Also, remember that the British pronounciation is different from the American dialect. British is closer to bizi , whereas American is distinctly bizI . In
messageBody:
Also, remember that the British pronounciation is different from the American dialect. British is closer to "bizi", whereas American is distinctly "bizI".

 

In American pronounciation, the terminal "-y" is for the most part always pronounced as "bizI".

From: "steveb_667" <sbartok1632@...>
Reply-To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Letter #26?
Date: Tue, 05 Dec 2006 01:30:03 -0000

Page #20 in the QS manual states that an unstressed terminal -Y sound
should be represented by letter #26 with letter #27 reserved for
stressed terminal -Y sound.

From a dry technical standpoint, in Junior Quikscript, it would be
appropriate to spell "busy" as "bizI" since this suffix rule is on
page #20 & Junior Quikscript ends on page #12. However, in Senior
Quikscript, "bizi" is appropriate.

--- In Read_Alphabet@ yahoogroups. com, "pete_a90" <pete_a90@.. .> wrote:
>
> I'm confused about this letter because according to both the manual
> and
> http://home. earthlink. net/~sbartok1632 /quik/qprojects/ qdict/qdic_ e/b.htm
>
> busy = bizi
>
> I would have thought it would be pronounced
>
> bizI instead (i.e. with letter #27 in place of the y).
>
